content.description: Start with both hands directly under graffiti on "V"-shaped sidepulls, and move right to two slot holds above the sandy bulge. Reset your feet, pop up to a small jug pocket, reset your feet, and blast up to the topout jugs.
content.protection: A pad and a spotter if you have one.

content.description:
This is on the Joe 97 Boulder. It starts in the same place that

Dagger to the Heart

starts. Instead of moving upward like

Dagger

the Heart, make a dynamic move to the "other" boulder that sits on top of Joe 97 (it looks like this slice of rock was once part of Joe 97 before it slid off). Get some technical feet and move up the "other" block on positive holds.
content.location:
This is on the west side of Joe 97 Boulder. Again, start right where

Dagger

the Heart to the Heart starts. Downclimb is anywhere on the south side of the boulder.

content.description: This is a nice compression problem, albeit reachy, for the first move. Sit start on the two vertical slots, make a long dead-point to a right hand pinch/sloper, set your feet and throw a heel, fire left hand to the side-pull, set feet again, fire to a right hand pinch, readjust, bump left hand up, feet swing, set feet high, and fire for the top.
content.location:
Located on the Joe 97 Boulder, this is just to the right of

All American Grinder

. Sit start on the two vertical slots.

content.description: Start directly under the Joe 97 graffiti with a left hand in a slot-pull and right on a slot. Fire right hand up to a side-pull, adjust your feet, reset your right hand, and dead-point to a two finger pocket, reset feet and lunge to the flat shelf, and lunge to the topout holds.
content.location: This is on the Joe 97 Boulder, in the main area.

content.description: Start on the right side of the boulder in a large jug.  Move left and then up over the nose of the boulder.  Top out on good jugs and walk off.
content.location: Take the first trail on the right as you enter the parking area.  "Joe 97" is spray painted on the boulder ~60 ft up the trail on the left hand side.

content.description: Start on the left side of the boulder on crimps.  Pull and heel hook your way up and right to the nose of the boulder and top out on good jugs.
content.location: Take the first trail on the right as you enter the parking area.  "Joe 97" is spray painted on the boulder ~60 feet up the trail on the left hand side.

content.description:
This is in Randall Chapman's guidebook to the area. Many of the routes listed in his book have names that differ from the Mountain Project listings, so this likely may also go by another name? It shares the start with

All American Grinder

but goes straight up (the "dyno") from the two pockets in the middle of the boulder. The difficulty seems very height-dependent and is likely much easier for tall people. The book lists it as V7, but for me at 5' 11", it felt easier, and I did not have to dyno. Still, it's a good problem and a one-move wonder. It's quite sunny and well suited for winter afternoons.
content.location:
Start on the south face of Joe 97 Boulder as for

All American Grinder

(called Low Stepper in Randall Chapman's guidebook).

content.description: Sit start with your hands in the crack about 2-3 feet off the ground, move up and left using slopers, and top out. The cruxes are the beginning of the climb and the top out. There is a slopey dish under the the boulder stacked on top of Joe 97 that makes the climb a lot easier. So use it if you want it to be a V3 route, or don't use it to keep the route at a higher grade.
content.protection: A pad or two and a spotter. There is an intimidating rock right below the topout.
content.location:
This is on the Joe 97 Boulder, on the Northern-most point. It is to the right of

Joe 97 (right)

.

content.description:
This problem is located on the west side of the Joe 97 Boulder. By no means am I claiming a FA, it's just a really fun problem, so I wanted to share. If you have any info on the problem, let me know and I'll make things right. The grade was shared to me by someone who had climbed it a while ago, but I thought it was a tough problem, so V5 sounded fine to me.

This starts on the left side of the west face on a diagonal rail. I've heard that in the past people have started on a lower, but better, hold. Move right with pockets and crimps and huecos. Once you have your hands on good holds, move upward on big slopers and poor feet. Top out.
content.location: It is located on the west side of the Joe 97 Boulder. Once on top, you'll see an obvious downclimb on the northwest side of the block. This rock sees a lot of sun in the afternoon, so if you're not a fan of that, I'd go early or wait until evening.
